bibl.title: Following the Wandering Trail of the Conquerors of Yellow Fever, by Philip Showalter Hench, [1954]

div1.p: In this outline, Hench lists and describes sites associated with the conquerors of yellow fever located in and near Havana. One list arranges the sites in chronological sequence, the other in geographical sequence.

div1.head: Following the Wandering Trail of the Conquerors of Yellow Fever, by Philip Showalter Hench, [1954]

list.head:
FOLLOWING THE WANDERING TRAIL OF THE CONQUERORS OF YELLOW FEVER
An Outline by Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.
list.item:
Arrangement: I. The trail as it wandered back and forth; the principal sites in
chronological sequence.

II. The sites rearranged as one might see them in geographical sequence
in Havana and Quemados; i.e. as one might make an auto tour in one day.

list.head: I. The Principal sites - Arranged chronologically.
list.item:
1. Finlay's home (1881), #156 Prado (in 1881 it was #52) where Dr. Finlay lived when he
developed (1879-1880) and first announced (1881) his mosquito theory and where
he made his earliest inoculations. (House now marked with a bronze tablet).

2. Cabana Barracks: The site was on hill “south” (to the right) of old Cabana fortress
(as one looks across the harbor from La Fuerza or La Punta).

item.p:
3. Quinta San Jose, Calzada Real, between Calle Jose Miguel Gomez and Calle Villalon,
Quemados de Marianao. Old house first connected to the yellow fever story
by the U. S. (Chaille) Commission, 1879; this was where Finlay made several
inoculations on Jesuit priests (1883) and at its rear, Reed et al set up
Camp Lazear, November 1900.
(“Calzada Real” is same as Calzada de Marianao.)

list.item:
4. Machina Pier, site of old Machina Wharf (San Pedro Street near San Francisco
Square), off which the MAINE sank, February 15, 1898.

5. City Hall of Havana, Plaza de Armas (between Obispo Street and O'Reilly Street) -
before 1898 the palace of the Spanish Captains-General; in 1900 the head-
quarters of the U.S. Governor-General of Cuba, Leonard Wood.

6. Supreme Court Building - Plaza de Armas at Tacon Street. In 1900 this was where
many of General Wood's headquarters staff were quartered and where so many
got sick (and later died); before 1900 the Segundo Cabo.

7. Large old white building on Calzada Real (just “west” of Calle Adolfo Castillo),
Quemados de Marianao. In 1900 it was General Lee's headquarters; also the
office of Major Kean, his chief surgeon; also of Captain Stark, Acting
Chief Surgeon during Kean's convalescence from yellow fever, July 1900.
(Now a gasoline station and cheap restaurant.) Prior to 1900 it was called the
Quinta Duranon (or old Toledo House), so I was told.

8. House: now 404 General Lee Street (in 1900, #20), (between Calzada Real and Marti
Street). This is where the 1900 epidemic of yellow fever first broke out,
Quemados de Marianao.

9. House at #102 Calzada Real (same number now as in 1900) where yellow fever next
struck. The house is on Real (or Calzada de Marianao) between General
Lee Street and Macoo Street.

item.p:
10. Grounds of Cuban Army Hospital (Hospital Agramonte of Ciudad Militar), Quemados.
This is the very site where the Post Hospital of Columbia Barracks was in 1900.

list.item:
11. Old site of Military Hospital #1 (1900 and before) where Agramonte worked in the
lab (and continued to do so even while a member of the Army Yellow Fever
Board) - now the old buildings of the Calixto Garcia Hospital on Principe
Hill near the Medical School, University of Havana. The Hospital is be-
tween Calle G and Calle Universidad.

12. #_____ General Lee Street (in 1900 #16), where General Kean lived in summer of
1900 and where he developed yellow fever (Just opposite what is now #303).

13. #303 General Lee Street (in 1900 #27) where Major Edmunds lived and died (and
where Kean caught his yellow fever) (across street from Major Kean's house)
“Southeast” corner of General Lee Street and Calle Rosendo Collazo (which
was Calle St. Frederico in 1900).

14. Site of medical officers' quarters, Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks on “north”
porch of which Yellow Fever Board held its meetings. See #10-A above.

item.p:
15. “Reed's laboratory” where Lazear began (early July 1900) to raise mosquitos -
see 10-C above.

X-1 Site of old quartel, Pinar del Rio (110 miles west of Havana) in which was the 15 -
bed carcel (prison-room) where Prisoner Haskins was the only one of 9 prisoners
to get yellow fever; visited by Agramonte July 19, by Reed July 21, by Lazear
during week of July 30: A turning point in the investigations. The quartel
blew up in 1910. It is now the site of two small twin school buildings, “Frank-
lin Roosevelt School” and “School of Americas.”

list.item:
16. General Lee's Headquarters, Calzada Real, Quemados, where Captain Stark (Acting
Chief Surgeon) reviewing Godfrey's reports, suspected that the “malaria”
at Pinar del Rio was yellow fever (see #7 above).

17. Back to medical officers' quarters. Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks, where Army
Board decided to investigate Finlay's mosquito theory - see 10-A.

18. #460 Aguacate Street, downtown Havana. In 1900 it was #110; where Dr. Finlay was
living then, and where Lazear went twice (once with Reed) to visit him and
got Finlay's mosquito larvae. (Finlay's home torn down and on this site
now is The Central Agency Limited. But I understand that Finlay's
(1900) home here was the exact counter-part of the old house next door
(except “in reverse”).

between Teneinte Rey
& Muralla Se

19. LaPlaya bathing beach, about 1 mile “north” of the former Columbia Barracks Post
Hospital (see #10 above) where Carroll went to “cool off” when he was
coming down with yellow fever (without knowing it) and where the medical
officers (1900) often went to swim and bathe.

20. Ward where Private Dean (“XY”) was quartered (Lazear's second successful case).
See #10vE.
21. Dr. Lazear's cottage where he took sick, September 16. See 10-B.
XIX -3 -

22. Los Animas Hospital (entrance off Avenida de Menocal). Here is the little
yellow fever ward where Dr. Lazear is supposed to have been bitten (and where
in 1900 Miss Clara Maass, the nurse who volunteered for yellow fever
inoculations by Gorgas and Guiteras, died). It is now marked with a
bronze tablet on the outside wall.

item.p:
23. Site of the “little yellow fever huts”. This is where Major Kean was cared for,
where Dr. Lazear died, where all the volunteers who got experimental yellow
fever were cared for (by Dr. Ames and Nurse Gust Lambert) - 375 feet north
of where old LayPlaya railroad crosses Santa Rosa Street (at “southwest”
corner of Cuban “Hospital Militar” - See #10). This is now a small empty
field just across the LaPlaya railroad tracks from the Cuban Army Hospital
grounds. (and the site of the “false Campamento Lazear.”)

It is where the “eastern” end of Calle Asuncion (Reparto Padre Zamora, Que-
mados de Marianao) hits the (abandoned) LaPlaya railroad track. The best
way to get there by car is (a) to turn “north” off Calzada Real onto General
Lee Street; turn left where Lee Street enters the hospital grounds, go “west”
along Santa Rosa Street and cross the single LaPlaya railroad track; one
block beyond track turn right (“north”) on Calle San Carlos (Rene Berndes), and
go one block to Asuncion; then get out of car and walk to right (“east”) to
small empty field (lot) beside railroad track;

or (b) Find Paseo Cuatro de Septiembre (in Marianao), go “north” on it to
Asuncion, then turn right to the “east” end of Asuncion;

or (c) Walk “north” (toward the sea) along the LaPlaya railroad out (track
was still there in 1952) about 375 feet: the 1900 grounds or the little
“yellow fever wards” (huts) began at the out and extended “west” (away from
the present Cuban army hospital grounds).

24. Site of former U. S. Army Cemetery (now abandoned) where Dr. Lazear (and others)
buried in 1900; re-interred 1901. It is along the “east” side of the La
Playa railroad tracks a little farther “north” than the site of the yellow
fever huts. (Dr. Nogueira is now locating it).

My old maps place it about 913 yards “north” of where Santa Rosa Street crosses
the LaPlaya railroad; it was just to the right side (“east”) of the railroad
track; i.e. between the LaPlaya railroad and the road (“Road to LaPlaya”)
which passes “north” through the “western” end of the Hospital Militar and
after curving a bit turns leftish and runs into Avenida Centrale and Gran
Boulevard to end at LaPlaya. The site of the cemetery may be about where
this “hospital road to LaPlaya”(?) passes the near end (south end) of the
military air-field, i.e. where the hospital touches the air-field. The
cemetery was between the LaPlaya railroad (on the left or “west”) and the old
“road to LaPlaya” which it faced (on the right or “east”).

X-2.Matanzas Harbor (100 miles east of Havana) where Reed's transport first stopped
(October 3, 1900) when he was returning to Cuba and where Kean met him and
told him details of Carroll and Dean. and Lazear

list.item:
25. Medical Officers' Quarters, Post Hospital, where Reed studied Lazear's notes
and “rediscovered” the “secret of yellow fever”, first “discovered” (but
not proven) by Finlay in 1881, discovered (and proved to himself and to
Reed, but not to the world) by Lazear (August 11 - September 16), and
re-discovered(and proven to the world) by Reed, Agramonte, Carroll, et al.
See #10

X-3. Indianapolis, Indiana: Old German House where Reed read the Board's first report
on October 26, 1900.

26. City Hall, Havana: - 2nd floor; fairly large room on the left front (left as one
looks at the building from the Plaza) which was General Wood's office
and where Reed, with Kean, got from Wood permission and support to establish
“Camp Lazear”: - the small room on left was room of Wood's secretary - it
has a single (corner) window; next room with two windows and checker-board
flooring was General Wood's former office; it is now the Mayor's formal
office, (not his “working office”); next large room is the main reception
hall, Care-taker will let you in.

item.p:
27. Camp Lazear Site. Building #1 (preserved) behind the Finca San Jose - home of
Senora Rojas, daughter of Dr. Rojas who loaned (rented) farm to Reed;
Calzada Real, Quemados, at right corner of Calle Jose Miguel Gomez (on the
gate of the Finca is the sign “San Jose”. Be sure to visit the Finca
(farm) or rather the present Quinta (house) San Jose. Senora Rojas has
her father's old 1900-1901 day-books with entries on Camp “Lezar”, Major
Mr. “Read” and “Camp Lazear.”

But the Camp Lazear site is approached via Calle Jose M. Gomez (corner of
the Finca San Jose, on Calzada Real). The former site of Building #2
(blown down in 1926) was exactly 80 yards in front of Building #1. Site
of tents was to the right (in the empty field) of Building #1 as you stand
there and look to where Building #2 was, - i.e. the only empty land re-
maining there which is not yet quarried away!

Also to be found are the ruins of the old lime-kiln and bath house of the
priests ( ruins of the one appears in one of the old Army photos of
Camp Lazear).

list.item:
28. “Old Delmonico's Restaurant” where dinner in honor of FinlayLazear, Reed, et al given
December 22, 1900 - second floor (in what is now the “Nobel Academy”) over
the “Press Wireless office,” Parque Centrale right next to D'Ingleterra
Hotel. Can walk up the stairs and look in the old restaurant site, now
cut up as rooms (offices) for the Nobel (Business) Academy.

29. Pan-American Congress held in Havana, February 1901, before which Reed presented
in English (and Agramonte in Spanish) the Board's second paper. Sessions
were held in both the Marti and the Tacon Theaters. I have never been
able to find out in which one Reed and Agramonte gave this paper, but
believe it was in the Marti Theater, which still stands at the corner
of Zulueta and Dragunes. The old Tacon Theater (now the National Theater)
is swallowed up by the Centro Gallego Building (Parque Centrals) which
entirely surrounds it and with which it is now “incorporated” (in its very
center). But a bit of it can be seen by going to the (rear) Consulado
Street entrance (delivery-entrance) and through it into a small court-yard.
A sign on the inner wall identifies the old Tacon Theater. Here the opening
and closing sessions of the Pan-American Congress were held, and I think the
regular sessions were held in the (smaller) Marti Theater.
